citation.article-title: Reinekea marinisedimentorum gen. nov., sp. nov., a novel gammaproteobacterium from marine coastal sediments
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Reinekea (Rei.ne.ke′a. N.L. fem. n. Reinekea derived from Reineke, geographical name of Reineke Island, Peter the Great Bay, Sea of Japan, Russia, the place where the bacterium was first isolated).
Gram-negative, heterotrophic, oxidase- and catalase-positive, rod-shaped and motile.
Sodium ions are essential for growth.
Growth occurs in 0·5–5 % NaCl and between 4 and 37 °C.
No growth is observed in >5 % NaCl or at 40 °C.
Facultatively anaerobic; acid is produced from some carbohydrates under anaerobic and aerobic conditions.
Polar lipids include phosphatidylglycerol, diphosphatidylglycerol, phosphatidylethanolamine, phosphatidylinositol and an unknown phospholipid.
Major fatty acids are C16 : 0, C16 : 1ω7c and C18 : 1ω7c.
Represents a main phylogenetic sublineage within the γ-Proteobacteria, showing remote relatedness to other marine and non-marine members of this class.
The type species is Reinekea marinisedimentorum.
